Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: An Unexplored Avenue of Striga Resistance in Maize
Award.AbstractNarration:
Striga is a parasitic plant that feasts through the roots of corn, sorghum, upland rice, millet, and cowpea, devastating these crops and the lives of people who depend on them in sub-Saharan Africa and other areas in the developing world. The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) notes that, while maize has the largest acreage of all field crops in Africa, the average yield (1.6 t/hectare) is less than 1/3 of that achieved per unit area elsewhere in the world. The situation is further exacerbated by widespread dispersal of Striga seeds that intermix with maize kernels and ears going to market. This EAGER project will test a potentially novel strategy for dealing with Striga infestation using a newly identified transposon-induced (non-transgenic) mutant of maize. This plant carries a mutation in a gene that encodes a carotenoid cleavage dioxygenase 8 (ccd8) and has been shown to produce little to no precursors for strigolactone (SL), a maize hormone that is sensed by the Striga parasite and is required as a chemo-signal for host location and germination of its own seeds. The non-transgenic nature of this new maize mutant also enhances prospects for its acceptance and use by peoples with diverse cultures.

This project will test the extent to which actual interactions between maize and Striga are affected by the partially-understood roles of strigolactone in plant biology. The specific objectives are to: 1) determine the degree of resistance to Striga seed germination and host attraction offered by the ccd8 mutation, and 2) test the concept that a relatively modest yield penalty in ccd8 maize can be countered without losing Striga resistance, by breeding strategies based on hybrid vigor and naturally-occurring genetic modifiers. If successful, this EAGER project will provide for a new strategy that could counter Striga-based yield losses that extend from 15% to 100%, thereby making maize production sustainable in Striga infested regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research here developed not only an unexpected source of maize resistance to Striga (“witchweed”), but also revealed fundamental genetic mechanisms regulating roles of maize strigolactone, a Striga stimulant as well as an endogenous maize hormone. Striga is a parasitic plant often deadly to maize. Crop yields can drop to near zero in Striga-infested areas of Africa and the developing world. Collectively, sub-Saharan yield losses due to Striga are estimated at $1 billion per year and affect the livelihood of nearly 100 million people. As such, Striga ranks among the greatest constraints to smallholder agriculture in Africa. The parasitic Striga is a flowering plant that sends its “root” inside the roots of corn, sorghum, upland rice, millet, and cowpea, where it devastates these crops and the lives of people who depend on them. Maize has the largest acreage of all field crops in Africa according to the FAO, but the average yield there is less than 1/3 of that per unit area elsewhere in the world. The Striga impact is  exacerbated by widespread dispersal of Striga seeds that intermix with maize kernels and ears going to market.

Our research identified and developed a new line of strigolactone-deficient maize that confers an unparalleled resistance to Striga. We have shared the new maize with collaborators in Africa who have tested it and enthusiastically integrated it into their breeding programs. The Striga-resistance of this maize line is due to a naturally-concurring (non-transgenic) mutation generated with NSF funds for exploring this approach to maize genetics. The resulting plants are thus suitable for diverse cultures and agricultural systems. The new Striga-resistance results from disruption of a single gene (carotenoid cleavage dioxygenase 8 [ccd8]) that normally mediates strigolactone formation. Although strigolactone has hormonal roles in maize, its deficiency confers Striga resistance. The parasitic Striga requires strigolactone as a chemo-signal for germination of its own seeds. A strigolactone deficiency thus allows the new maize line to stay “under the radar” of Striga seeds.

Although typical yield losses from Striga dramatically exceed those of strigolactone-deficient plants, we have nonetheless demonstrated two successful strategies for countering this deficiency. Both are based on fundamental mechanisms of strigolactone function, which we found to differ with genetic background. We thus employed, first, hybrid vigor to restore maximal yield. This success also revealed the presence of genetic modifiers in key lines that uniquely enhanced ear and kernel features of strigolactone-deficient maize. Existence of these modifiers will be invaluable for breeding Striga-resistant maize as well as exploiting maize diversity to dissect fundamental genetic mechanisms underlying roles of strigolactone.
